noun.description: An action that violates a law, treaty, or other ruling.
examples: young persons who commit offenses bear responsibility for their contraventions

phrases: If an organisation says something is a bargain it may be in contravention of the consumer protection act.
That's in contravention of his contract.
I saw a lot of things at those buildings that might be in contravention of the housing code, he says.
Police chiefs believe such rulings would not be in contravention of human rights legislation although the club has yet to take such action.
It appears to be in contravention of international law and the UN Charter.
origin: Mid 16th century: via French from medieval Latin contraventio(n-), from late Latin contravenire (see contravene).
